docs.lead_paragraph: A reader asked last week about the extension of Cobra benefits for those with disabilities. Following our reply, Steven S. Landis, a lawyer in Manhattan, suggested we take a closer look at a related state law recently passed in New York. Here's what we found.
docs.abstract: Many workers in New York State can qualify for 36 months of Cobra benefits after a layoff.
docs.snippet: Many workers in New York State can qualify for 36 months of Cobra benefits after a layoff.

docs.lead_paragraph: Have you ever received a doctor's bill for the amount your insurance plan didn't cover? The practice is called "balance billing,'' and as Walecia Konrad explains in today's Patient Money, it's a bill you may not be required to pay.

headline.main: A Medical Bill You May Not Have to Pay

docs.abstract: Have you ever received a doctor's bill for the amount your insurance plan didn't cover? The practice is called "balance billing,'' and as Walecia Konrad explains in today's Patient Money, it's a bill you may not be required to pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Friday Reading: Asking for More Financial Aid

docs.abstract: The growing number of parents asking for more financial aid, the crackdown on companies that don't pay overtime and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a health care provider’s cost is higher than the insurance company’s rate, patients can receive an invoice for the difference: the dreaded “balance billing.”
